com.jmex.physics
Class PhysicsWorld

java.lang.Object
  com.jmex.physics.PhysicsWorld

public class PhysicsWorld
extends java.lang.Object

PhysicsWorld is what you add objects with physical properties to. In order to do that, you need to create a PhysicsObject.

To create the PhysicsWorld you need to call PhysicsWorld.create() (once only). Then it's enough calling PhysicsWorld.getInstance() everytime you need a reference to it.

In order to step the simulation forward you need to call update() from your game loop. Look at the SimpleTest for a basic example on how to do all this.

There are three different ways of updating the world: QUICK, FAST and SIMULATION. SIMULATION is the slowest but most accurate one - QUICK and FAST trades accuracy for speed. QUICK is the default one. You set them by calling:

PhysicsWorld.setStepFunction(PhysicsWorld.SF_STEP_SIMULATION),
PhysicsWorld.setStepFunction(PhysicsWorld.SF_STEP_QUICK),
PhysicsWorld.setStepFunction(PhysicsWorld.SF_STEP_FAST),

Look at the StepFunctionTest on how to do this.

TODO: Fix PhysicsSynchronizer not being removed when using the removeObject method.

Author:
Ahmed Al-Hindawi, Nicki de Bruyn, Per Thulin

Method Detail

create

public static PhysicsWorld create()
Creates a new PhysicsWorld. If one already exists, it returns the existing one. Some standard values are set:

gravity = Earths

step interactions = 15

step size = 0.02

update rate = 0 (update as fast as possible)

step function = SF_STEP_QUICK

Returns:
The singleton.

getInstance

public static PhysicsWorld getInstance()
Forces a return of the singleton instance.

Returns:
The singleton.

addObject

public boolean addObject(PhysicsObject obj)
Adds a PhysicsObject to the simulation.

Parameters:
obj - The object to add.
Returns:
If the object was added or not. It won't be if is already attached.

removeObject

public void removeObject(PhysicsObject obj)
Removes a PhysicsObject from the simulation.

Parameters:
obj - The object to remove.

createPhysicalEntity

public org.odejava.Placeable createPhysicalEntity(PhysicsObject obj)
Creates a physical representation (either a Body in case of a dynamic object, or a PlaceableGeom in case it's static) from a PhysicsObject. To know which geometry it should be using, it looks at the jME geometry of that object, and from there decides which shape that will fit the best.

Note: the user should NEVER touch this method , since it's only used by the PhysicsObject (to obtain its physical entity), during its creation.

Parameters:
obj - The object to create the geometry from.

createJointEntity

public org.odejava.Joint createJointEntity(Joint joint)
Creates the ODE representation of a joint. The joint type is determied by a call to Joint.getType(). If no joint type mathces, a JmeException is thrown with the approperiate message.

Note: the user should NEVER touch this method , since it's only used by the Joint (to obtain its type), during its creation.

Parameters:
joint -
Returns:

setStepSize

public void setStepSize(float stepSize)
Set how much to step by each time.

Parameters:
stepSize - The step size to set. Default is 0.02.

getStepSize

public float getStepSize()
Obtains how far to step by each update call.

Returns:
The current step size. Default is 0.02.

setUpdateRate

public void setUpdateRate(int ups)
Sets how many updates per second that is wanted. Default is running as fast as possible (e.g. -1).

Parameters:
ups - The updaterate. Note: cannot be 0.

getUpdateRate

public int getUpdateRate()
Returns how many updates per second we run at. Default is running as fast as possible (0).

Returns:
The updaterate. Default is 0.

update

public void update(float tpf)
Steps the world forward. Perform all calculations and detect collisions. Should be called every frame.

Note, that if you have set an update rate, this method will check with the timer if it should do any logic. If not, it escapes.

warmUp

public void warmUp(int iterations)
Runs the update method of this physics World for x number of times with an update. This is used to "warm up" and let the physical objects settle down and not let the user see the objects falling down due to gravity. Obviously if the scene depends on gravity, this should not be called.

Parameters:
iterations - The number of iterations to warm up.

cleanup

public void cleanup()
Clean up the system. Should be called before ending your application.

setGravity

public void setGravity(com.jme.math.Vector3f gravity)
Earths gravity = (0, -9.82, 0) (Sweden)

Parameters:
gravity - The gravity vector.

getGravity

public com.jme.math.Vector3f getGravity()
Gets the gravity of this world.

Returns:
The current gravity.

getGravity

public com.jme.math.Vector3f getGravity(com.jme.math.Vector3f store)
A memory-usage optimized way to get to the gravity. It fills the passed Vector3f with the gravity values.

Parameters:
store - The Vector3f to fill with values.
Returns:
The Vector3f sent as parameter.

setStepInteractions

public void setStepInteractions(int stepInteractions)
Number of interactions, higher gives better accuracy but lower speed in case of many simultaneous collisions. Default is 15.

Parameters:
stepInteractions - The stepInteractions to set.

getStepInteractions

public int getStepInteractions()
Gets the stepInteractions of this world.

Returns:
The stepInteractions of this world.

setStepFunction

public void setStepFunction(int stepFunction)
Sets the method which we use to update the world. It can be one of the following: - SF_STEP_SIMULATION (The slowest but most accurate step function) - SF_STEP_FAST (A faster but lees accurate alternative) - SF_STEP_QUICK (The step function that has superseded SF_STEP_FAST) Default is SF_STEP_QUICK.

Parameters:
stepFunction - The stepFunction to set.

getStepFunction

public int getStepFunction()
Gets the method which we use to update the world.

Returns:
The current step function being used.
